stagedir.dir: Enter Flavius, Murellus, and certain Commoners over the stage.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Calphurnia!

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: Peace ho, Caesar speaks.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Calphurnia!

speech.speaker: CAL.
speech.line: Here, my lord.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Stand you directly in Antonio’s way
When he doth run his course. Antonio!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Caesar, my lord?

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Forget not in your speed, Antonio,
To touch Calphurnia; for our elders say,
The barren, touched in this holy chase,
Shake off their sterile curse.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I shall remember:
When Caesar says, “Do this,” it is perform’d.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Set on, and leave no ceremony out.

speech.speaker: SOOTH.
speech.line: Caesar!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Ha? Who calls?

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: Bid every noise be still; peace yet again!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Who is it in the press that calls on me?
I hear a tongue shriller than all the music
Cry “Caesar!” Speak, Caesar is turn’d to hear.

speech.speaker: SOOTH.
speech.line: Beware the ides of March.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: What man is that?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Set him before me, let me see his face.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Fellow, come from the throng, look upon Caesar.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: What say’st thou to me now? Speak once again.

speech.speaker: SOOTH.
speech.line: Beware the ides of March.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: He is a dreamer, let us leave him. Pass.

stagedir.dir: Sennet. Exeunt. Manent Brutus and Cassius.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: The games are done, and Caesar is returning.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve,
And he will (after his sour fashion) tell you
What hath proceeded worthy note today.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: I will do so. But look you, Cassius,
The angry spot doth glow on Caesar’s brow,
And all the rest look like a chidden train:
Calphurnia’s cheek is pale, and Cicero
Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes
As we have seen him in the Capitol,
Being cross’d in conference by some senators.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Casca will tell us what the matter is.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Antonio!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Caesar?

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Let me have men about me that are fat,
Sleek-headed men and such as sleep a-nights.
Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look,
He thinks too much; such men are dangerous.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Fear him not, Caesar, he’s not dangerous,
He is a noble Roman, and well given.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Would he were fatter! But I fear him not.
Yet if my name were liable to fear,
I do not know the man I should avoid
So soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much,
He is a great observer, and he looks
Quite through the deeds of men. He loves no plays,
As thou dost, Antony; he hears no music;
Seldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort
As if he mock’d himself, and scorn’d his spirit
That could be mov’d to smile at any thing.
Such men as he be never at heart’s ease
Whiles they behold a greater than themselves,
And therefore are they very dangerous.
I rather tell thee what is to be fear’d
Than what I fear; for always I am Caesar.
Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,
And tell me truly what thou think’st of him.

stagedir.dir: Sennet. Exeunt Caesar and his Train. Casca stays.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!
He was quick mettle when he went to school.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: So is he now in execution
Of any bold or noble enterprise,
However he puts on this tardy form.
This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit,
Which gives men stomach to disgest his words
With better appetite.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: And so it is. For this time I will leave you;
Tomorrow, if you please to speak with me,
I will come home to you; or, if you will,
Come home to me, and I will wait for you.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I will do so; till then, think of the world.

speech.speaker: CIC.
speech.line: Good even, Casca; brought you Caesar home?
Why are you breathless, and why stare you so?

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: Are not you mov’d, when all the sway of earth
Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero,
I have seen tempests when the scolding winds
Have riv’d the knotty oaks, and I have seen
Th’ ambitious ocean swell, and rage, and foam,
To be exalted with the threat’ning clouds;
But never till tonight, never till now,
Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.
Either there is a civil strife in heaven,
Or else the world, too saucy with the gods,
Incenses them to send destruction.

speech.speaker: CIC.
speech.line: Why, saw you any thing more wonderful?

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: A common slave—you know him well by sight—
Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn
Like twenty torches join’d; and yet his hand,
Not sensible of fire, remain’d unscorch’d.
Besides—I ha’ not since put up my sword—
Against the Capitol I met a lion,
Who glaz’d upon me, and went surly by,
Without annoying me. And there were drawn
Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women,
Transformed with their fear, who swore they saw
Men, all in fire, walk up and down the streets.
And yesterday the bird of night did sit
Even at noon-day upon the market-place,
Howting and shrieking. When these prodigies
Do so conjointly meet, let not men say,
“These are their reasons, they are natural”;
For I believe they are portentous things
Unto the climate that they point upon.

speech.speaker: CIC.
speech.line: Indeed, it is a strange-disposed time;
But men may construe things after their fashion,
Clean from the purpose of the things themselves.
Comes Caesar to the Capitol tomorrow?

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: He doth; for he did bid Antonio
Send word to you he would be there tomorrow.

speech.speaker: CIC.
speech.line: Good night then, Casca; this disturbed sky
Is not to walk in.

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: Farewell, Cicero.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: A Roman.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Casca, by your voice.

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: Your ear is good. Cassius, what night is this!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: A very pleasing night to honest men.

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Those that have known the earth so full of faults.
For my part, I have walk’d about the streets,
Submitting me unto the perilous night;
And thus unbraced, Casca, as you see,
Have bar’d my bosom to the thunder-stone;
And when the cross blue lightning seem’d to open
The breast of heaven, I did present myself
Even in the aim and very flash of it.

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens?
It is the part of men to fear and tremble
When the most mighty gods by tokens send
Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: You are dull, Casca; and those sparks of life
That should be in a Roman you do want,
Or else you use not. You look pale, and gaze,
And put on fear, and cast yourself in wonder,
To see the strange impatience of the heavens;
But if you would consider the true cause
Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,
Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,
Why old men, fools, and children calculate,
Why all these things change from their ordinance,
Their natures, and preformed faculties,
To monstrous quality—why, you shall find
That heaven hath infus’d them with these spirits,
To make them instruments of fear and warning
Unto some monstrous state.
Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man
Most like this dreadful night,
That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars
As doth the lion in the Capitol—
A man no mightier than thyself, or me,
In personal action, yet prodigious grown,
And fearful, as these strange eruptions are.

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: ’Tis Caesar that you mean; is it not, Cassius?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Let it be who it is; for Romans now
Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors;
But woe the while, our fathers’ minds are dead,
And we are govern’d with our mothers’ spirits;
Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: Indeed, they say, the senators tomorrow
Mean to establish Caesar as a king;
And he shall wear his crown by sea and land,
In every place, save here in Italy.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I know where I will wear this dagger then;
Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius.
Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong;
Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat;
Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass,
Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron,
Can be retentive to the strength of spirit;
But life, being weary of these worldly bars,
Never lacks power to dismiss itself.
If I know this, know all the world besides,
That part of tyranny that I do bear
I can shake off at pleasure.

speech.speaker: CASCA.
speech.line: Stand close a while, for here comes one in haste.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: ’Tis Cinna, I do know him by his gait,
He is a friend. Cinna, where haste you so?

speech.speaker: CIN.
speech.line: To find out you. Who’s that? Metellus Cimber?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: No, it is Casca, one incorporate
To our attempts. Am I not stay’d for, Cinna?

speech.speaker: CIN.
speech.line: I am glad on’t. What a fearful night is this!
There’s two or three of us have seen strange sights.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Am I not stay’d for? Tell me.

speech.speaker: CIN.
speech.line: Yes, you are.
O Cassius, if you could
But win the noble Brutus to our party—

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Be you content. Good Cinna, take this paper,
And look you lay it in the praetor’s chair,
Where Brutus may but find it; and throw this
In at his window; set this up with wax
Upon old Brutus’ statue. All this done,
Repair to Pompey’s Porch, where you shall find us.
Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?

speech.speaker: CIN.
speech.line: All but Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone
To seek you at your house. Well, I will hie,
And so bestow these papers as you bade me.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: That done, repair to Pompey’s theatre.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: What, Lucius, ho!
I cannot by the progress of the stars
Give guess how near to day. Lucius, I say!
I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly.
When, Lucius, when? Awake, I say! What, Lucius!

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: It must be by his death; and for my part,
I know no personal cause to spurn at him,
But for the general. He would be crown’d:
How that might change his nature, there’s the question.
It is the bright day that brings forth the adder,
And that craves wary walking. Crown him that,
And then I grant we put a sting in him
That at his will he may do danger with.
Th’ abuse of greatness is when it disjoins
Remorse from power; and to speak truth of Caesar,
I have not known when his affections sway’d
More than his reason. But ’tis a common proof
That lowliness is young ambition’s ladder,
Whereto the climber-upward turns his face;
But when he once attains the upmost round,
He then unto the ladder turns his back,
Looks in the clouds, scorning the base degrees
By which he did ascend. So Caesar may;
Then lest he may, prevent. And since the quarrel
Will bear no color for the thing he is,
Fashion it thus: that what he is, augmented,
Would run to these and these extremities;
And therefore think him as a serpent’s egg,
Which, hatch’d, would as his kind grow mischievous,
And kill him in the shell.
You know not what you do. Do not consent
That Antony speak in his funeral.
Know you how much the people may be mov’d
By that which he will utter?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: By your pardon—
I will myself into the pulpit first,
And show the reason of our Caesar’s death.
What Antony shall speak, I will protest
He speaks by leave and by permission;
And that we are contented Caesar shall
Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.
It shall advantage more than do us wrong.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I know not what may fall, I like it not.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Mark Antony, here take you Caesar’s body.
You shall not in your funeral speech blame us,
But speak all good you can devise of Caesar,
And say you do’t by our permission;
Else shall you not have any hand at all
About his funeral. And you shall speak
In the same pulpit whereto I am going,
After my speech is ended.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Be it so;
I do desire no more.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Prepare the body then, and follow us.

scene.line: You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?

speech.speaker: CAES. SERV.
speech.line: I do, Mark Antony.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.

speech.speaker: CAES. SERV.
speech.line: He did receive his letters, and is coming,
And bid me say to you by word of mouth—
O Caesar!—

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Thy heart is big; get thee apart and weep.
Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes,
Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,
Began to water. Is thy master coming?

speech.speaker: CAES. SERV.
speech.line: He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanc’d.
Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,
No Rome of safety for Octavius yet;
Hie hence, and tell him so. Yet stay awhile,
Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse
Into the market-place. There shall I try,
In my oration, how the people take
The cruel issue of these bloody men,
According to the which thou shalt discourse
To young Octavius of the state of things.
Lend me your hand.

speech.speaker: ALL PLEBEIANS.
speech.line: We will be satisfied! Let us be satisfied!

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Then follow me, and give me audience, friends.
Cassius, go you into the other street,
And part the numbers.
Those that will hear me speak, let ’em stay here;
Those that will follow Cassius, go with him;
And public reasons shall be rendered
Of Caesar’s death.

speech.speaker: 1. PLEB.
speech.line: I will hear Brutus speak.

speech.speaker: 2. PLEB.
speech.line: I will hear Cassius, and compare their reasons,
When severally we hear them rendered.

stagedir.dir: Exit Cassius with Second Plebeian and some of the Plebeians.

scene.line: Here comes his body, mourn’d by Mark Antony, who, though he had no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying, a place in the commonwealth, as which of you shall not? With this I depart, that, as I slew my best lover for the good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself, when it shall please my country to need my death.

speech.speaker: ALL PLEBEIANS.
speech.line: Live, Brutus, live, live!

speech.speaker: 1. PLEB.
speech.line: Bring him with triumph home unto his house.

speech.speaker: 3. PLEB.
speech.line: Give him a statue with his ancestors.

speech.speaker: 4. PLEB.
speech.line: Let him be Caesar.

speech.speaker: 5. PLEB.
speech.line: Caesar’s better parts
Shall be crown’d in Brutus.

speech.speaker: 1. PLEB.
speech.line: We’ll bring him to his house
With shouts and clamors.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: My countrymen—

speech.speaker: 3. PLEB.
speech.line: Peace, silence! Brutus speaks.

speech.speaker: 1. PLEB.
speech.line: Peace ho!

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Good countrymen, let me depart alone,
And, for my sake, stay here with Antony.
Do grace to Caesar’s corpse, and grace his speech
Tending to Caesar’s glories, which Mark Antony
(By our permission) is allow’d to make.
I do entreat you, not a man depart,
Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot,
Take thou what course thou wilt!

speech.speaker: CIN. POET.
speech.line: I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar,
And things unluckily charge my fantasy.
I have no will to wander forth of doors,
Yet something leads me forth.

speech.speaker: 1. PLEB.
speech.line: What is your name?

speech.speaker: 2. PLEB.
speech.line: Whither are you going?

speech.speaker: 3. PLEB.
speech.line: Where do you dwell?

speech.speaker: 4. PLEB.
speech.line: Are you a married man or a bachelor?

speech.speaker: 2. PLEB.
speech.line: Answer every man directly.

speech.speaker: 1. PLEB.
speech.line: Ay, and briefly.

speech.speaker: 4. PLEB.
speech.line: Ay, and wisely.

speech.speaker: 3. PLEB.
speech.line: Ay, and truly, you were best.

speech.speaker: CIN. POET.
speech.line: What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then to answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and truly: wisely, I say, I am a bachelor.

speech.speaker: 2. PLEB.
speech.line: That’s as much as to say, they are fools that marry. You’ll bear me a bang for that, I fear. Proceed directly.

speech.speaker: CIN. POET.
speech.line: Directly, I am going to Caesar’s funeral.

speech.speaker: 1. PLEB.
speech.line: As a friend or an enemy?

speech.speaker: CIN. POET.
speech.line: As a friend.

speech.speaker: 2. PLEB.
speech.line: That matter is answer’d directly.

speech.speaker: 4. PLEB.
speech.line: For your dwelling—briefly.

speech.speaker: CIN. POET.
speech.line: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.

speech.speaker: 3. PLEB.
speech.line: Your name, sir, truly.

speech.speaker: CIN. POET.
speech.line: Truly, my name is Cinna.

speech.speaker: 1. PLEB.
speech.line: Tear him to pieces, he’s a conspirator.

speech.speaker: CIN. POET.
speech.line: I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet.

speech.speaker: 4. PLEB.
speech.line: Tear him for his bad verses, tear him for his bad verses.

speech.speaker: CIN. POET.
speech.line: I am not Cinna the conspirator.

speech.speaker: 4. PLEB.
speech.line: It is no matter, his name’s Cinna. Pluck but his name out of his heart, and turn him going.

speech.speaker: 3. PLEB.
speech.line: Tear him, tear him! Come, brands ho, fire-brands! To Brutus’, to Cassius’; burn all! Some to Decius’ house, and some to Casca’s; some to Ligarius’. Away, go!

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all the Plebeians dragging off Cinna.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: These many then shall die, their names are prick’d.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Your brother too must die; consent you, Lepidus?

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: I do consent—

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Prick him down, Antony.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Upon condition Publius shall not live,
Who is your sister’s son, Mark Antony.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him.
But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar’s house;
Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine
How to cut off some charge in legacies.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: What? Shall I find you here?

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Or here or at the Capitol.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Stand ho!

speech.speaker: LUCIL.
speech.line: Give the word ho! And stand.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: What now, Lucilius, is Cassius near?

speech.speaker: LUCIL.
speech.line: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come
To do you salutation from his master.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: He greets me well. Your master, Pindarus,
In his own change, or by ill officers,
Hath given me some worthy cause to wish
Things done undone; but if he be at hand
I shall be satisfied.

speech.speaker: PIN.
speech.line: I do not doubt
But that my noble master will appear
Such as he is, full of regard and honor.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: He is not doubted. A word, Lucilius,
How he receiv’d you; let me be resolv’d.

speech.speaker: LUCIL.
speech.line: With courtesy and with respect enough,
But not with such familiar instances,
Nor with such free and friendly conference,
As he hath us’d of old.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Thou hast describ’d
A hot friend cooling. Ever note, Lucilius,
When love begins to sicken and decay
It useth an enforced ceremony.
There are no tricks in plain and simple faith;
But hollow men, like horses hot at hand,
Make gallant show and promise of their mettle;
But when they should endure the bloody spur,
They fall their crests, and like deceitful jades
Sink in the trial. Comes his army on?

speech.speaker: LUCIL.
speech.line: They mean this night in Sardis to be quarter’d.
The greater part, the horse in general,
Are come with Cassius.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: That you have wrong’d me doth appear in this:
You have condemn’d and noted Lucius Pella
For taking bribes here of the Sardians;
Wherein my letters, praying on his side,
Because I knew the man, was slighted off.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: You wrong’d yourself to write in such a case.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: In such a time as this it is not meet
That every nice offense should bear his comment.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself
Are much condemn’d to have an itching palm,
To sell and mart your offices for gold
To undeservers.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I, an itching palm?
You know that you are Brutus that speaks this,
Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: The name of Cassius honors this corruption,
And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Chastisement?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Remember March, the ides of March remember:
Did not great Julius bleed for justice’ sake?
What villain touch’d his body, that did stab
And not for justice? What? Shall one of us,
That struck the foremost man of all this world
But for supporting robbers, shall we now
Contaminate our fingers with base bribes?
And sell the mighty space of our large honors
For so much trash as may be grasped thus?
I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon,
Than such a Roman.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Brutus, bait not me,
I’ll not endure it. You forget yourself
To hedge me in. I am a soldier, I,
Older in practice, abler than yourself
To make conditions.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Go to; you are not, Cassius.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I am.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: I say you are not.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Urge me no more, I shall forget myself;
Have mind upon your health; tempt me no farther.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Away, slight man!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Is’t possible?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Hear me, for I will speak.
Must I give way and room to your rash choler?
Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: O ye gods, ye gods, must I endure all this?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: All this? Ay, more. Fret till your proud heart break;
Go show your slaves how choleric you are,
And make your bondmen tremble. Must I bouge?
Must I observe you? Must I stand and crouch
Under your testy humor? By the gods,
You shall digest the venom of your spleen
Though it do split you; for, from this day forth,
I’ll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter,
When you are waspish.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Is it come to this?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: You say you are a better soldier:
Let it appear so; make your vaunting true,
And it shall please me well. For mine own part,
I shall be glad to learn of noble men.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: You wrong me every way; you wrong me, Brutus:
I said an elder soldier, not a better.
Did I say “better”?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: If you did, I care not.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: When Caesar liv’d, he durst not thus have mov’d me.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Peace, peace, you durst not so have tempted him.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I durst not?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: What? Durst not tempt him?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: For your life you durst not.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Do not presume too much upon my love,
I may do that I shall be sorry for.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: You have done that you should be sorry for.
There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats;
For I am arm’d so strong in honesty
That they pass by me as the idle wind,
Which I respect not. I did send to you
For certain sums of gold, which you denied me;
For I can raise no money by vile means.
By heaven, I had rather coin my heart
And drop my blood for drachmaes than to wring
From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash
By any indirection. I did send
To you for gold to pay my legions,
Which you denied me. Was that done like Cassius?
Should I have answer’d Caius Cassius so?
When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous
To lock such rascal counters from his friends,
Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts,
Dash him to pieces!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I denied you not.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: You did.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I did not. He was but a fool that brought
My answer back. Brutus hath riv’d my heart.
A friend should bear his friend’s infirmities;
But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: I do not, till you practice them on me.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: You love me not.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: I do not like your faults.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: A friendly eye could never see such faults.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: A flatterer’s would not, though they do appear
As huge as high Olympus.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come,
Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius,
For Cassius is a-weary of the world;
Hated by one he loves, brav’d by his brother,
Check’d like a bondman, all his faults observ’d,
Set in a note-book, learn’d, and conn’d by rote,
To cast into my teeth. O, I could weep
My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger,
And here my naked breast; within, a heart
Dearer than Pluto’s mine, richer than gold:
If that thou be’st a Roman, take it forth.
I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart:
Strike as thou didst at Caesar; for I know,
When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better
Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Sheathe your dagger.
Be angry when you will, it shall have scope;
Do what you will, dishonor shall be humor.
O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb
That carries anger as the flint bears fire,
Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark,
And straight is cold again.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Hath Cassius liv’d
To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus,
When grief and blood ill-temper’d vexeth him?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: When I spoke that, I was ill-temper’d too.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: And my heart too.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: O Brutus!

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Have not you love enough to bear with me,
When that rash humor which my mother gave me
Makes me forgetful?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Yes, Cassius, and from henceforth,
When you are over-earnest with your Brutus,
He’ll think your mother chides, and leave you so.

stagedir.dir: Enter a Poet to Lucilius and Titinius as they stand on guard.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: How now? What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: POET.
speech.line: For shame, you generals! What do you mean?
Love, and be friends, as two such men should be,
For I have seen more years, I’m sure, than ye.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Ha, ha! How vildly doth this cynic rhyme!

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Get you hence, sirrah; saucy fellow, hence!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Bear with him, Brutus, ’tis his fashion.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: I’ll know his humor, when he knows his time.
What should the wars do with these jigging fools?
Companion, hence!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Away, away, be gone!

speech.speaker: BRU.
CAS.
speech.line: I did not think you could have been so angry.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Of your philosophy you make no use,
If you give place to accidental evils.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Ha? Portia?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: She is dead.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: How scap’d I killing when I cross’d you so?
O insupportable and touching loss!
Upon what sickness?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Impatient of my absence,
And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony
Have made themselves so strong—for with her death
That tidings came. With this she fell distract,
And (her attendants absent) swallow’d fire.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: And died so?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Even so.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: O ye immortal gods!

stagedir.dir: Enter Boy Lucius with wine and tapers.

speech.line: My gown.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Every thing is well.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Good night, my lord.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Good night, good brother.

speech.speaker: TIT. AND MES.
speech.line: Good night, Lord Brutus.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Farewell every one.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all but Brutus and Lucius.

speech.speaker: VAR.
speech.line: Calls my lord?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep;
It may be I shall raise you by and by
On business to my brother Cassius.

speech.speaker: VAR.
speech.line: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: I will not have it so. Lie down, good sirs,
It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.
Look, Lucius, here’s the book I sought for so;
I put it in the pocket of my gown.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I was sure your lordship did not give it me.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.
Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile,
And touch thy instrument a strain or two?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Ay, my lord, an’t please you.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: It does, my boy.
I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: It is my duty, sir.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: I should not urge thy duty past thy might;
I know young bloods look for a time of rest.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I have slept, my lord, already.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: It was well done, and thou shalt sleep again;
I will not hold thee long. If I do live,
I will be good to thee.
How ill this taper burns! Ha! Who comes here?
I think it is the weakness of mine eyes
That shapes this monstrous apparition.
It comes upon me. Art thou any thing?
Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil,
That mak’st my blood cold, and my hair to stare?
Speak to me what thou art.

speech.speaker: GHOST.
speech.line: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Why com’st thou?

speech.speaker: GHOST.
speech.line: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Well; then I shall see thee again?

speech.speaker: GHOST.
speech.line: Ay, at Philippi.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Why, I will see thee at Philippi then.
Fellow thou, awake!

speech.speaker: VAR.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: CLAU.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?

speech.speaker: BOTH VAR. AND CLAU.
speech.line: Did we, my lord?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Ay. Saw you any thing?

speech.speaker: VAR.
speech.line: No, my lord, I saw nothing.

speech.speaker: CLAU.
speech.line: Nor I, my lord.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius;
Bid him set on his pow’rs betimes before,
And we will follow.

speech.speaker: BOTH VAR. AND CLAU.
speech.line: It shall be done, my lord.

stagedir.dir: Enter Octavius, Antony, and their army.

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: Prepare you, generals.
The enemy comes on in gallant show;
Their bloody sign of battle is hung out,
And something to be done immediately.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Octavius, lead your battle softly on
Upon the left hand of the even field.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Upon the right hand I, keep thou the left.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Why do you cross me in this exigent?

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: I do not cross you; but I will do so.

stagedir.dir: Drum. Enter Brutus, Cassius, and their army; Lucilius, Titinius, Messala, and others.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Why now blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark!
The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Ho, Lucilius, hark, a word with you.

stagedir.dir: Lucilius and then Messala stand forth.

speech.speaker: LUCIL.
speech.line: My lord.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Messala!

speech.speaker: MES.
speech.line: What says my general?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Messala,
This is my birthday; as this very day
Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala.
Be thou my witness that against my will
(As Pompey was) am I compell’d to set
Upon one battle all our liberties.
You know that I held Epicurus strong,
And his opinion; now I change my mind,
And partly credit things that do presage.
Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign
Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perch’d,
Gorging and feeding from our soldiers’ hands,
Who to Philippi here consorted us.
This morning are they fled away and gone,
And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites
Fly o’er our heads, and downward look on us
As we were sickly prey. Their shadows seem
A canopy most fatal, under which
Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.

speech.speaker: MES.
speech.line: Believe not so.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I but believe it partly,
For I am fresh of spirit, and resolv’d
To meet all perils very constantly.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Even so, Lucilius.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Now, most noble Brutus,
The gods today stand friendly, that we may,
Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age!
But since the affairs of men rests still incertain,
Let’s reason with the worst that may befall.
If we do lose this battle, then is this
The very last time we shall speak together:
What are you then determined to do?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Even by the rule of that philosophy
By which I did blame Cato for the death
Which he did give himself—I know not how,
But I do find it cowardly and vile,
For fear of what might fall, so to prevent
The time of life—arming myself with patience
To stay the providence of some high powers
That govern us below.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Then, if we lose this battle,
You are contented to be led in triumph
Thorough the streets of Rome?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: No, Cassius, no. Think not, thou Roman,
That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome;
He bears too great a mind. But this same day
Must end that work the ides of March begun.
And whether we shall meet again I know not;
Therefore our everlasting farewell take:
For ever, and forever, farewell, Cassius!
If we do meet again, why, we shall smile;
If not, why then this parting was well made.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: For ever, and forever, farewell, Brutus!
If we do meet again, we’ll smile indeed;
If not, ’tis true this parting was well made.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Why then lead on. O that a man might know
The end of this day’s business ere it come!
But it sufficeth that the day will end,
And then the end is known. Come ho, away!

scene.scenelocation: The plains of Philippi. The battlefield.
scene.line: Let them set on at once; for I perceive
But cold demeanor in Octavio’s wing,
And sudden push gives them the overthrow.
Ride, ride, Messala, let them all come down.

scene.scenelocation: The plains of Philippi. Another part of the battlefield.

speech.speaker: PIN.
speech.line: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off;
Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord;
Fly therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: This hill is far enough. Look, look, Titinius,
Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: They are, my lord.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Titinius, if thou lovest me,
Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him
Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops
And here again, that I may rest assur’d
Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: I will be here again, even with a thought.

scene.line: Even with the sword that kill’d thee.

speech.speaker: PIN.
speech.line: So, I am free; yet would not so have been,
Durst I have done my will. O Cassius,
Far from this country Pindarus shall run,
Where never Roman shall take note of him.

speech.speaker: MES.
speech.line: It is but change, Titinius; for Octavius
Is overthrown by noble Brutus’ power,
As Cassius’ legions are by Antony.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: These tidings will well comfort Cassius.

speech.speaker: MES.
speech.line: Where did you leave him?

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: All disconsolate,
With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.

speech.speaker: MES.
speech.line: Is not that he that lies upon the ground?

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: He lies not like the living. O my heart!

speech.speaker: MES.
speech.line: Is not that he?

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: No, this was he, Messala,
But Cassius is no more. O setting sun,
As in thy red rays thou dost sink tonight,
So in his red blood Cassius’ day is set!
The sun of Rome is set. Our day is gone,
Clouds, dews, and dangers come; our deeds are done!
Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.

speech.speaker: MES.
speech.line: Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.
O hateful error, melancholy’s child,
Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men
The things that are not? O error, soon conceiv’d,
Thou never com’st unto a happy birth,
But kill’st the mother that engend’red thee!

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: What, Pindarus? Where art thou, Pindarus?

speech.speaker: MES.
speech.line: Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet
The noble Brutus, thrusting this report
Into his ears; I may say “thrusting” it;
For piercing steel, and darts envenomed,
Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus
As tidings of this sight.

speech.speaker: TIT.
speech.line: Hie you, Messala,
And I will seek for Pindarus the while.

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Enter Brutus, Messala, young Cato, Strato, Volumnius, and Lucilius.

speech.speaker: CATO.
speech.line: Brave Titinius!
Look whe’er he have not crown’d dead Cassius!

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Are yet two Romans living such as these?
The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!
It is impossible that ever Rome
Should breed thy fellow. Friends, I owe more tears
To this dead man than you shall see me pay.
I shall find time, Cassius; I shall find time.
Come therefore, and to Thasos send his body;
His funerals shall not be in our camp,
Lest it discomfort us. Lucilius, come,
And come, young Cato, let us to the field,
Labio and Flavio set our battles on.
’Tis three a’ clock, and, Romans, yet ere night
We shall try fortune in a second fight.

scene.scenelocation: The plains of Philippi. Another part of the battlefield.

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Enter Brutus, Messala, young Cato, Lucilius, and Flavius.

speech.speaker: CATO.
speech.line: What bastard doth not? Who will go with me?
I will proclaim my name about the field.
I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
A foe to tyrants, and my country’s friend.
I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!

scene.line: O young and noble Cato, art thou down?
Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius,
And mayst be honor’d, being Cato’s son.

speech.speaker: 1. ANT. SOL.
speech.line: Yield, or thou diest.

speech.speaker: LUCIL.
speech.line: Only I yield to die;
There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight:
Kill Brutus, and be honor’d in his death.

speech.speaker: 1. ANT. SOL.
speech.line: We must not. A noble prisoner!

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.

speech.speaker: CLI.
speech.line: Statilius show’d the torchlight, but, my lord,
He came not back. He is or ta’en or slain.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Sit thee down, Clitus; slaying is the word,
It is a deed in fashion. Hark thee, Clitus.

speech.speaker: DAR.
speech.line: Shall I do such a deed?

speech.speaker: CLI.
speech.line: O Dardanius!

speech.speaker: DAR.
speech.line: O Clitus!

speech.speaker: CLI.
speech.line: What ill request did Brutus make to thee?

speech.speaker: DAR.
speech.line: To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.

speech.speaker: CLI.
speech.line: Now is that noble vessel full of grief,
That it runs over even at his eyes.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Come hither, good Volumnius; list a word.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: What says my lord?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Why, this, Volumnius:
The ghost of Caesar hath appear’d to me
Two several times by night; at Sardis once,
And this last night, here in Philippi fields.
I know my hour is come.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Not so, my lord.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.
Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes;
Our enemies have beat us to the pit.

speech.speaker: CLI.
speech.line: Fly, fly, my lord, there is no tarrying here.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Farewell to you, and you, and you, Volumnius.
Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep;
Farewell to thee too, Strato. Countrymen,
My heart doth joy that yet in all my life
I found no man but he was true to me.
I shall have glory by this losing day
More than Octavius and Mark Antony
By this vile conquest shall attain unto.
So fare you well at once, for Brutus’ tongue
Hath almost ended his live’s history.
Night hangs upon mine eyes, my bones would rest,
That have but labor’d to attain this hour.

speech.speaker: CLI.
speech.line: Fly, my lord, fly.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Hence! I will follow.

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Retreat. Enter Antony, Octavius, Messala, Lucilius, and the army.
